metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. Central Bank of India Ltd.

facts.text: Petitioner held five shares in the share capital of the Central Bank of India Ltd., a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1882, with registered office at Bombay.
Bank sold the five shares to a third party in purported exercise of its right of lien for recovery of a debt due to it from the petitioner.
Transfer of shares was registered in the books of the Bank in the year 1937.
Petitioner instituted a series of proceedings in the High Court at Bombay on its original and appellate jurisdiction challenging the validity of the said sale and transfer.
Latest proceeding: suit filed against the Bank in 1951 wherein the plaint was rejected on 2nd March, 1951, under Order 7, Rule 11(d), of the Code of Civil Procedure as barred by limitation.

Petitioner prays that all adverse orders made in previous proceedings be quashed and the High Court be directed to have the suit set down to be heard as undefended and pronounce judgment against the respondent or make such orders as it thinks fit.
Order rejecting plaint was appealable, but petitioner did not prefer an appeal on the ground that all Judges of the High Court were disqualified due to interest in the Bank or prejudice against him.

legal_issues.text: Whether Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(1) of the Constitution protect against violation of fundamental rights by private conduct of the Central Bank of India Ltd., or are limited to State action.
Whether Article 31(1) should be construed independently of Article 31(2) to cover deprivations by private individuals.

petitioner_arguments.text: Central Bank violated petitioner's fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31(1) by selling shares under lien.
Article 31(1) should be construed apart from Article 31(2); its language covers infringements by private individuals; omission of 'State' in clause 1 while present in clause 2 and other articles.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 31(1), Seventh Schedule entries 33 (Union List), 36 (State List), 42 (Concurrent List), Article 246

petitioner_arguments.text: Legislative history: Section 299(1) of Government of India Act, 1935, corresponding to Article 31(1), was omitted in draft Article 19 (later 31) but restored, indicating intent for independent operation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 299(1), Government of India Act, 1935; Draft Constitution history

respondent_arguments.text: Certain other objections to the maintainability of the petition.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner has misconceived his remedy; Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(1) not intended to prevent wrongful individual acts or provide protection against merely private conduct; they protect against State action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article 19 deals with freedoms against State action other than legitimate exercise of power to regulate private rights in public interest.

court_reasoning.text: Article 31(1) is a declaration of fundamental right of private property in negative form like Article 21; 'save by authority of law' excludes private violations as no private individual authorized by law to deprive another.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if read apart from clause 2, Article 31(1) prohibits unauthorised governmental action.

court_reasoning.text: Argument on legislative lists fallacious; legislatures competent to authorize deprivation under other entries like entry 1 of Lists.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article 31(1) itself contemplates law authorizing deprivation.

court_reasoning.text: Legislative history does not support; Section 299(1) of 1935 Act never interpreted as prohibiting private deprivations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restoration leads to no inference supporting petitioner's contention.

court_reasoning.text: Reference to Chiranjit Lal v. Union of India unnecessary for present petition.

holdings.text: Neither Article 19(1)(f) nor Article 31(1) was intended to prevent wrongful individual acts or provide protection against merely private conduct; violation of property rights by individuals not within purview.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chiranjit Lal v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner's reliance on observations of Das J. that Article 31(1) enunciates general principle distinct from clause 2; court finds unnecessary to examine.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Core provisions invoked; court holds they apply only against State action, not private conduct.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for rejection of plaint in High Court suit as barred by limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Corresponding provision to Article 31(1); legislative history discussed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution Seventh Schedule
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner's argument on legislative competence rejected.

outcome.summary: The petition under Article 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(1) against the private acts of the Central Bank fails on preliminary ground as these articles protect only against State action, not private conduct; petition misconceived.

key_quotes.text: Neither article 19(1)(f) nor article 31(1) on its true construction was intended to prevent wrongful individual acts or to provide protection against merely private conduct.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding dismissing petition on preliminary ground.

key_quotes.text: The words 'save by authority of law' in clause (1) of article 31 show that it is a prohibition of unauthorised governmental action against private property.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects petitioner's interpretation of Article 31(1) covering private deprivations.
